page.title: 08Farming in Caerhun Parish
page.content: Hill-farming goes back generations. Sons are trained in agriculture and join their fathers on the farms. The average farm is a smallholding comprising 200 acres of mountain grazing land and 30 acres of lowland pasture stocked with Welsh mountain sheep and Welsh cattle. Sheep's wool, which is coarse, is sold for carpet manufacture; lambs are ready for market when they weigh approx. 35 kilos. The cattle are cross-bred with Charolais bulls to produce lean beef and the calves sold at 750 kilos. Farmers grow their own crops for silage and fodder. Machinery is either owned or rented. Sheds near farmhouses are for the wintering and concentrated feeding of sheep before lambing. Farmers' wives help on the farm at busy times e.g. lambing and haymaking.
